item.title: Lime Bike by Foreshore under Blackfriars Bridge, 19th February
item.description:
URGENT ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARD: There are three abandoned e-bikes (2 Voi and 1 Lime) located on the River Thames foreshore directly adjacent to Doggett's Coat and Badge (1 Blackfriars Bridge, SE1 9UD). Current Status: The bikes are on the tidal riverbank and are currently being submerged by the rising tide. As of 21:48, the Lime bike is already underwater. Hazard Details: Submerged lithium-ion batteries pose a significant environmental risk to the Thames ecosystem. Saltwater contact can cause internal short-circuiting, corrosion, and the release of toxic heavy metals like lithium, cobalt, and nickel. Urgency: Immediate specialist recovery is needed before the next high tide at approximately 03:18 AM tomorrow (Feb 20) fully submerges the units. The bikes are currently at the bottom of the stone stairs leading to the foreshore.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Blackfriars Bridge, City of London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Fly Tipping on Lawn Road and Amberley Court, 19th February
item.description:
Amberley Court, Lawn Road: Rubble, a foam mattress and a television has been dumped next to our recycling bins at Amberley Court. We have CCTV footage and car registration number recorded on CCTV camera. Just outside Amberley Court where the telephone generator boxes are located there is rubble and rubbish dumped. Can you please collect these from these premises

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Lawn Road, New Beckenham, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: 2 E-Bikes on Foreshore, 19th February
item.description:
Two abandoned Voi e-bikes are currently located on the River Thames foreshore (South Bank), directly below the stone stairs next to Doggett's Coat and Badge (1 Blackfriars Bridge, SE1 9UD). They were spotted at 20:28 on Thursday, 19th Feb. The bikes are below the high-tide line and at risk of being submerged or swept away, which poses an environmental hazard due to the batteries. Immediate recovery is required before the next high tide.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Blackfriars Bridge, City of London
Report on FixMyStreet
